results.title: Come to Daddy
results.brief_description: Chris Cunningham’s infamous film clip for electronic artist Aphex Twins is a terrifying trip into the dark side. The clip begins ominously enough with a young girl skipping down a grotty laneway. When an old lady comes across the child, the little girl reveals a creepy mutated face, which bears a disturbing resemblance to Aphex Twin Richard D. James. As the music begins to freak out, with the refrain ‘I want your soul’ being chanted through the distortion, the helpless old lady ultimately finds herself face to face with sheer horror.

results.title: Sports amateurs
results.creator_credit: Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People's Republic of China
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “China Today”.
Newsreel presenting a rich variety of physical activities in China including the martial arts; winter sports such as skating and skiing; track and field; and roller skating.

results.title: Mother and child
results.creator_credit: Francis Fuchs, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
Explores the changing relationship between mother and child from birth to school age. Considers two common family crises involving separation - when either mother or child goes to hospital and the arrival of a new baby. Narrated by Hugh David.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francis Fuchs, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and BBC-TV

results.title: How far how soon? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Eurfron Gwynne Jones and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
This program covers the range and pattern of normal physical development and, where possible, relates this to the emotional changes which occur. However, children of the same chronological age may vary enormously in their true maturity. This has implications for school assessment, relationships and the early choice of future careers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eurfron Gwynne Jones and British Broadcasting Corporation
